comment.body: I don't think there are any constants exposed from the header files into this context. In which case I don't think it's worth the effort to add constants to expose just for this purpose.

pull_request.title: Fixing OpenSSL SHA2 incremental API integration
pull_request.body:
Possibly fixes #1452. Fixes issues in #1420.

- Corrects SHA2 API documentation
- Checks all SHA2 OpenSSL API return values
- Fixes SHA384 and SHA512 incremental API implementations
- Corrects testing for these APIs
- Enhances test vectors to avoid re-occurrence of problem

* [yes] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [no] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.body: Let's keep it as `test_hash.c`; in principal one could add other hash algorithms to it.  And in some sense, it does behave differently than `test_aes.c` and `test_sha3.c`: the AES and SHA-3 ones test against internal specified test vectors, where as `test_hash.c` just computes the hash of the supplied input which needs to be externally checked against another implementation or test vector.

comment.body: These `cp` commands look "brittle": What if any of the library versions change? The docker build will not succeed any more...

pull_request.title: Size optimization ngtcp2
pull_request.body:
Hi,
I have refactored the Dockerfiles for ngtcp2 to use multi-stage build. This reduces the size of each docker image to 32 MB.

Thank you for reviewing!

Edit: ngtcp2 has been moved to openssl3.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -23,10 +24,12 @@ extern "C" {
  * Macro for terminating the program if x is
  * a null pointer.
  */
-#define OQS_EXIT_IF_NULLPTR(x)  \
-    do {                        \
-        if ( (x) == (void*)0 )  \
+#define OQS_EXIT_IF_NULLPTR(x)    \
comment.body:
Changed macro to always state where the problem occurs in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1454/commits/5f8d02c9c2651b9a5f3eca0364457a5b271a473a. 

I'd suggest looking into improving this in the future: What was the rationale for all these `void` functions? Maybe someone would like to raise an issue documenting what this is about and how it could be improved (at least stating more specifically what/where a problem occurred, if it occurred, such that users of `liboqs` have a better idea where to look for possible program termination causes).

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -141,7 +142,7 @@ parameter-sets:
     no-secret-dependent-branching-checked-by-valgrind: true
     large-stack-usage: false
 - name: SPHINCS+-Haraka-192f-robust
-  claimed-nist-level: 3
+  claimed-nist-level: 2
comment.body: @dstebila Why is there still a reference to a Haraka version? And why did the claimed NIST level change? Would it be more appropriate to remove all references to all no-longer supported SPHINCS+ variants from this YML file? FWIW, I did the same for Kyber90s and DilithiumAES as `copy_from_upstream` did not have the automation for this.

pull_request.title: Update SPHINCS+
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1249.

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [Yes] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [No] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

milestone.description: See https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1245#issuecomment-1319218926 for table of algorithm updates.

repo.name: liboqs

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -23,10 +24,12 @@ extern "C" {
  * Macro for terminating the program if x is
  * a null pointer.
  */
-#define OQS_EXIT_IF_NULLPTR(x)  \
-    do {                        \
-        if ( (x) == (void*)0 )  \
+#define OQS_EXIT_IF_NULLPTR(x)    \
comment.body: I think one reason for all these void functions is that the implementers of all the various PQ implementations we're using were working with SHA/AES APIs that didn't have return values -- they were assumed to just always work.  It would be very intrusive to go back to all of those calls deeply in the source code and change them all to have error handling.  We shouldn't forget about this if and when we start on the APIs for some of the other projects on the production track in the Foundation.

comment.body:
> Changed macro to always state where the problem occurs in [5f8d02c](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/commit/5f8d02c9c2651b9a5f3eca0364457a5b271a473a).

I think using `__LINE__` and `__FILE__` macros would've been better to pinpoint the source of the error, but I won't hold up the merge for this since it's not specific to this PR.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -141,7 +142,7 @@ parameter-sets:
     no-secret-dependent-branching-checked-by-valgrind: true
     large-stack-usage: false
 - name: SPHINCS+-Haraka-192f-robust
-  claimed-nist-level: 3
+  claimed-nist-level: 2
comment.body:
> I didn't realize that copy_from_upstream wouldn't clean that all up. 

I didn't either when doing https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1455. All it needed was removal of the no longer needed algs from https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/docs/algorithms/sig/sphincs.yml (in this case) and re-running `copy_from_upstream`.

pull_request.title: Update SPHINCS+
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1249.

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [Yes] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [Yes] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)
* [ ] TODO: Ensure all references to the removed variants (Haraka) are removed.

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->
